Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Nutritional and health risk assessment pre-screening tool based on 3D optical scanning
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project will be that it can save hundreds of thousands of dollars in health assessment costs by reducing costs associated with manual labor for the individualized care required at biometric screenings and the amount of time spent by medical experts. It will allow practitioners to "triage" their screenings by identifying people who are at high risk of developing metabolic and cardiovascular diseases for further in-depth evaluations. Moreover, this I-Corps project can reduce legal liability and risk associated with biometric screenings as the technology relies on 3D optical scanning technology, which is non-invasive and non-intrusive.

This I-Corps project will be one of the first to commercialize a non-invasive, non-intrusive, and fully automated health pre-screening tool based on 3D optical scanning. It is a web application that analyzes a 3D optical scan of a human subject and provides a detailed report on the subject's fitness and wellness status. A unique feature of the web application is that it can accommodate data from most currently available 3D optical scanners whose current system outputs are machine-specific and whose outputs are now very limited in their contents. More specifically, the technology quantifies a subject's body size and shape by applying geometrical mathematics on the subject's 3D optical scan and then uses machine learning approaches to estimate the subject's fitness and wellness status including the subject's body composition and risk of chronic diseases such as diabetes and heart disease.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A person’s body size and shape are related to their level of adiposity and health risks. Body size and shape are typically evaluated in medical settings by measuring weight, height, and waist circumference with a tape measure. Weight and height are combined as body mass index, weight divided by height squared, as a global health index.

            The value of these simple and practical body size and shape evaluations is limited and they do not accurately describe a person’s adiposity or health risk. However, a major change is taking place in the health care industry: safe, rapid, and low-cost body size and shape evaluations are now being made possible with automated three-dimensional (3D) optical scanners. Hundreds of body measurements can be made in a few seconds that yield detailed information on body size, shape, and composition. Our group has pioneered this technology through local and federal grants.

            Our starting hypothesis for the NSF I-Corps grant was that the proposed 3D optical technology when placed in health screening settings would save employers money by identifying people at high risk of developing chronic diseases. As we began our customer interviews with key decision makers in large corporate wellness programs, our premise was that 3D optical scans would identify people at health risk and thereby reduce the need for additional screening tests. What we soon learned was that these costs to employers were modest but that the major cost came from participant recidivism. That is, great expense went into enrolling employees into the program and initial testing, but that investment was lost when people dropped out after several months. Hence, there was no financial upside to their program built on the assumption that people would remain enrolled and get long term benefit by reducing weight, lowering blood cholesterol, and reducing blood pressure.

            These interviews were a powerful motivation for us to modify our original hypothesis. Accordingly, we refined your product value proposition such that baseline and longitudinal 3D optical scans with appropriate participant feedback would improve long term enrollment and thus reduce costs by keeping them healthy. We continued our interviews with this concept in mind and we were pleased to learn from key company managers that they endorsed our idea. Accordingly, we further refined our product description, software, and market position. As we reached our last series of interviews we captured the interest of a foundation that is supporting the next phase of our research and product development.

            In sum, we:
            -Learned through the training offered by the NSF I-Corps program the major steps to think "as an entrepreneur" instead of focusing on a technology developed in a laboratory setting; Evaluated the team cohesion and to established personal and professional relationships between team members.

            _ Developed a working methodology, including planning for cost and time, management and reporting while being in a startup-like, fast paced environment.

            -The Escowell (our company name) team successfully completed 102 interviews, among which 97 were in-person interviews. Team members traveled throughout the entire program to many exhibitions and conferences during which they were able to perform the interviews.

              The key activities of Escowell are (1) to develop a platform for researchers

to collect data and to publish papers to the results of the pilot tests to validate the value-proposition hypothesis.

            The key resources are: (1) intellectual including the clinical data and academic publications, (2) physical including online cloud services and data storage and (3) human including the data analysists, mathematicians, software developers and technical support experts.

            Many opportunities have been offered by NSF I-Corps program for training and professional development. Thanks to the weekly trainings, the team members were able to learn all key points as well as many techniques to approach and communicate with different stakeholders of the project. This intensive training allowed the entrepreneurial and co-entrepreneurial leads to discover what was never taught in their academic journeys as well as mentors that also developed their professional business skills.
            Finally, the I-Corps journey has also been a personal experience for all members, and all team members were grateful to be emerged during the seven weeks into this intense program that brought them outside of their comfort zone, to be fully immersed in a start-up pace.

 


Last Modified: 02/05/2021
Modified by: Sima Sobhiyeh
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: A person’s body size and shape are related to their level of adiposity and health risks. Body size and shape are typically evaluated in medical settings by measuring weight, height, and waist circumference with a tape measure. Weight and height are combined as body mass index, weight divided by height squared, as a global health index. The value of these simple and practical body size and shape evaluations is limited and they do not accurately describe a person’s adiposity or health risk. However, a major change is taking place in the health care industry: safe, rapid, and low-cost body size and shape evaluations are now being made possible with automated three-dimensional (3D) optical scanners. Hundreds of body measurements can be made in a few seconds that yield detailed information on body size, shape, and composition. Our group has pioneered this technology through local and federal grants. Our starting hypothesis for the NSF I-Corps grant was that the proposed 3D optical technology when placed in health screening settings would save employers money by identifying people at high risk of developing chronic diseases. As we began our customer interviews with key decision makers in large corporate wellness programs, our premise was that 3D optical scans would identify people at health risk and thereby reduce the need for additional screening tests. What we soon learned was that these costs to employers were modest but that the major cost came from participant recidivism. That is, great expense went into enrolling employees into the program and initial testing, but that investment was lost when people dropped out after several months. Hence, there was no financial upside to their program built on the assumption that people would remain enrolled and get long term benefit by reducing weight, lowering blood cholesterol, and reducing blood pressure. These interviews were a powerful motivation for us to modify our original hypothesis. Accordingly, we refined your product value proposition such that baseline and longitudinal 3D optical scans with appropriate participant feedback would improve long term enrollment and thus reduce costs by keeping them healthy. We continued our interviews with this concept in mind and we were pleased to learn from key company managers that they endorsed our idea. Accordingly, we further refined our product description, software, and market position. As we reached our last series of interviews we captured the interest of a foundation that is supporting the next phase of our research and product development. In sum, we: -Learned through the training offered by the NSF I-Corps program the major steps to think "as an entrepreneur" instead of focusing on a technology developed in a laboratory setting; Evaluated the team cohesion and to established personal and professional relationships between team members. _ Developed a working methodology, including planning for cost and time, management and reporting while being in a startup-like, fast paced environment. -The Escowell (our company name) team successfully completed 102 interviews, among which 97 were in-person interviews. Team members traveled throughout the entire program to many exhibitions and conferences during which they were able to perform the interviews. The key activities of Escowell are (1) to develop a platform for researchers to collect data and to publish papers to the results of the pilot tests to validate the value-proposition hypothesis. The key resources are: (1) intellectual including the clinical data and academic publications, (2) physical including online cloud services and data storage and (3) human including the data analysists, mathematicians, software developers and technical support experts. Many opportunities have been offered by NSF I-Corps program for training and professional development. Thanks to the weekly trainings, the team members were able to learn all key points as well as many techniques to approach and communicate with different stakeholders of the project. This intensive training allowed the entrepreneurial and co-entrepreneurial leads to discover what was never taught in their academic journeys as well as mentors that also developed their professional business skills. Finally, the I-Corps journey has also been a personal experience for all members, and all team members were grateful to be emerged during the seven weeks into this intense program that brought them outside of their comfort zone, to be fully immersed in a start-up pace.
